answers.answer: Dear Pam:As you are well aware, spinal surgery is an "if'y" thing and usually the only patient population that really has a good outcome are those with mechanical type pain.  That is pain with movement.  Surgery for other reasons is not as well documented with good outcomes.  In some respects the second opinion is correct and rehab is truely the initial choice for benefit.  I would push the rehab (in a center with good PT's and rehab physicians) as best you can.  Frankly, I imagine that you will feel somesort of pain, but hopefully in reduced intensity.  Hang-in there and do your best at rehab.  It will pay off in the long run.Sincerely,CCF Neuro MD

question: HELP!  NEED ADVICE FAST!I had microdisketomy surgery at L4/L5 in April 1998 at Hughston Sports Medicine Hospital (orthopedic surgeon).  Pain really never went away and continuously got worse.Had Lumbar Laminectomy with Microscopic Diskectomy at L4/L5 in March 1999 (neurosurgeon).  Pain and numbness in right leg still present.  Had an MRI in October which indicated another piece of disk ruptured.Went to Emory University Hospital to see another neurosurgeon in October for 2nd opinion and had a myelogram.  His diagnosis confirmed what my doctor saw.  He did state that studies have shown that people who exercise and people who opt to have surgery are at the same place in four years.  My doctor here in Columbus, GA gave me some back exercises to do for one month to see if they will help, but I continue to be in pain, which is bearable and not constant, but the pain is still there and my leg continuosly stays weak.My question - will exercise help or will this progressively get worse and I have to have surgery for the third time?  What's to say that the third time is a charm?  I need to know what to do before the end of the year as I've already met my deductibles for this year and my insurance would pay 100%!  Thank you!
title: Laminectomy for the 3rd time!
